body:
We could enable in our test suite to capture https://openjdk.org/jeps/520 i.e. `jdk.MethodTrace#filter=sun.reflect.*` (if that work?) and collect if after startup we have any reflective activities (we have it in smallrye config IIRC, but still - we could filter out few stacktraces by default). wdyt @cescoffier ?

In any case, I'll communicate with my team (app services perf team) to verify if is a type of metric which can be interesting for change point detection too.

NOTE: https://sap.github.io/SapMachine/jfrevents/25.html#methodtrace shows the Hotspot reference for it.
I fear that won't be enough. We have component using reflection a lot and no other choices (Kafka client)

>  fear that won't be enough

I would enable it selectively based on the extension tests (e.g. most of panache tests shouldn't...? and same for hibernate...?) - if we can enable it in our Quarkus test suite

In this precise case, the use of reflection is inevitable as the Panache projection facility allows projecting on any class and dynamically building the query using reflection to find the good constructor.

Of course, as you said, it could be optimized.
We can also cache it if it's too costly, but I fear we cannot built it at build time as there is no way to know which class would be used for projection.

It's fine if cannot happen at build time but I would have expected that if the query configuration is equivalent to the select one (which fail due to a missed check at https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/blob/71b94dd392f01194fa6a9b9d4bad28f2527cccc4/extensions/panache/hibernate-orm-panache-common/runtime/src/main/java/io/quarkus/hibernate/orm/panache/common/runtime/CommonPanacheQueryImpl.java#L115) it can still goes to the fast path.
Probably this requires some heuristic or lookahead, and thus will save just this case, not when a more wider query is required.
For the latter the suggested strategies (better string accumulation and caching annotation checks on ClassValue) could help.
I talked with @brunobat and @lucamolteni and I understood better the problem you mentioned @loicmathieu üôè

Well, actually we could scan any class annotated with `@ProjectedConstructor` or `@ProjectedFieldName` and find _some_ of those projection types at build time.

Then we could scan any class using `PanacheQuery` and any method calling `PanacheQuery.project` to collect any constant class argument to find more remaining projection types.

Once we have all these types, we can start building a `Map<Class,String>` for projection queries at build time and it will be hit most of the time.

Alternately, we could indeed have a runtime cache of projection queries per projection types ü§∑ This is probably a lot simpler.

But I have a feeling we'll just be pushing the problem down the ORM layer, because once we've generated our `select new Foo(a, b, c)‚Ä¶` query, ORM will still have to use reflection to find the proper constructor to invoke with the results and this will likely have the same problem as we just moved, no?

Thanks for the analysis @FroMage , is accurate

re
> ORM will still have to use reflection to find the proper constructor to invoke with the results and this will likely have the same problem as we just moved, no?

I think the bigger problem here is the scanning for annotations and gathering constructor's parameters and the stealthy string builder resizing (happening over and over); in 7 minutes of test it has allocated ~22 GB of byte[] just for the latter, or ~50 MB/sec with 2 cores not fully loaded.
The reflective construction/invocation maybe will be a problem, or maybe not - but in @mbellade tests for https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/issues/43692#issuecomment-2587226423 the accessors reflective ops were more relevant than the entity reflective allocation(s)
We could start by starting the string buffer with a 1024 size and see if this issue dissapears?

Writing a ClassValue<SomeCaching> caching should work decently still - re the StringBuilder, you can just collect strings in an array list (quickly looking at the code eh..) and once you have the overall size, allocate a single one properly sized, too.

IIRC @Sanne warned me about class value which can leak, but I don't remember precisely TBH

I don't remember if @brunobat can run any commit of quarkus - if he can, it should be easy to play with some patches and see if it helps
